ocil:boolean_question.ocil:question_text: For each namespace in the cluster, review the rights assigned to the default service account. There should be no cluster or local roles assigned to the default other than the defaults. Is it the case that default service account is used and is not unique?

For each pod in the cluster, review the pod specification and ensure that pods that do not need to explicitly communicate with the API server have automountServiceAccountToken configured to false. Is it the case that service account tokens are automounting?

To verify that root-ca-file is configured correctly, run the following command: $ oc get configmaps config -n openshift-kube-controller-manager -ojson | jq -r '.data["config.yaml"]' | jq -r '.extendedArguments["root-ca-file"]' The output should return a configured certificate authority file. Is it the case that <tt>root-ca-file</tt> is not configured</tt>?

To verify that service-account-credentials is configured correctly, run the following command: $ oc get configmaps config -n openshift-kube-controller-manager -ojson | jq -r '.data["config.yaml"]' | jq -r '.extendedArguments["use-service-account-credentials"]' The value of use-service-account-credentials should be true. Is it the case that <tt>use-service-account-credentials</tt> is set to <tt>false</tt>?

To verify that secure-port is configured correctly, run the following command: $ oc get configmaps config -n openshift-kube-controller-manager -ojson | jq -r '.data["config.yaml"]' | jq '.extendedArguments["secure-port"][]' Verify that it's using an appropriate port (the value is not 0). Is it the case that <tt>secure-port</tt> is not configured to use a secure port?

To verify that service-account-private-key-file is configured correctly, run the following command: $ oc get configmaps config -n openshift-kube-controller-manager -ojson | jq -r '.data["config.yaml"]' | jq -r '.extendedArguments["service-account-private-key-file"]' The output should return a configured private key file. Is it the case that <tt>service-account-private-key-file</tt> does not exist or is configured properly?

To verify that port is configured correctly, run the following command: $ oc get configmaps config -n openshift-kube-controller-manager -ojson | jq -r '.data["config.yaml"]' | jq '.extendedArguments["port"][]' Verify that it's disabled (the value is 0). Is it the case that <tt>port</tt> is not disabled?

To verify that terminated-pod-gc-threshold is configured correctly, run the following command: $ oc get configmaps config -n openshift-kube-controller-manager -ojson | jq -r '.data["config.yaml"]' | jq -r '.extendedArguments["terminated-pod-gc-threshold"]' The returned value of terminated-pod-gc-threshold should be greater than zero. Is it the case that <tt>terminated-pod-gc-threshold</tt> is not enabled?

To verify that RotateKubeletServerCertificate is configured correctly, run the following command: $ oc get configmaps config -n openshift-kube-controller-manager -ojson | jq -r '.data["config.yaml"]' | jq -r '.extendedArguments["feature-gates"]' The output should return RotateKubeletServerCertificate=true. Is it the case that <tt>RotateKubeletServerCertificate</tt> argument is set to <tt>false</tt> in the <tt>controllerArguments</tt> options?

Verify on OpenShift namespaces that network policies are in use: $ oc get networkpolicy --all-namespaces Is it the case that the NetworkPolicy plugin is not configured or network policies are not in use?

Verify on OpenShift that the NetworkPolicy plugin is being used: $ oc get networkpolicy
A network policy should be properly configured to create network segmentation. Is it the case that the NetworkPolicy plugin is not configured or network policies are not in use?

To review the wildcard usage in roles, run the following commands: $ oc get roles --all-namespaces -o yaml $ oc get clusterroles -o yaml Review the output and ensure that wildcard use is limited to a small subset as possible. Is it the case that wildcards are in use by more roles than necessary?

To verify that the cluster-debugger role is configured correctly, run the following command: $ oc get clusterroles cluster-debugger -o jsonpath='{.rules[0].nonResourceURLs}' and verify that the /debug/pprof path is included there. Is it the case that The <tt>cluster-debugger</tt> role isn't protecting <tt>/debug/pprof</tt>?

To review the cluster-admin role, run the following command: $ oc get clusterrolebinding -o json | jq '.items[] | select(.metadata.name | startswith("cluster-admin"))' Review the output and ensure that authorized users have the cluster-admin role. Is it the case that cluster-admin role is in use by more personnel then necessary?

To review the wildcard usage in roles, run the following commands: $ oc get roles --all-namespaces -o yaml $ oc get clusterroles -o yaml Review the output and ensure that wildcard use is limited to a small subset as possible. Is it the case that wildcards are in use by more roles than necessary?

Inspect each SCC returned from running the following command: $ oc get scc Review each SCC and determine that allowPrivilegeEscalation is either completely disabled, or that allowPrivilegeEscalation is only enabled to a small set of containers and SCCs. Is it the case that allowPrivilegeEscalation is set to true or too many SCCs have allowPrivilegeEscalation enabled?

Inspect each SCC returned from running the following command: $ oc get scc Review each SCC and determine that either NET_RAW or ALL is either completely disabled as a list entry under requiredDropCapabilities, or that either NET_RAW or ALL is only enabled to a small set of containers and SCCs. Is it the case that NET_RAW does not exist or is configured in defaultAddCapabilities or allowedCapabilities?

Inspect each SCC returned from running the following command: $ oc get scc Review each SCC and determine that allowHostIPC is either completely disabled, or that allowHostIPC is only enabled to a small set of containers and SCCs. Is it the case that allowHostIPC is set to true or too many SCCs have allowHostIPC enabled?

Inspect each SCC returned from running the following command: $ oc get scc Review each SCC and determine that all capabilities are either completely disabled as a list entry under requiredDropCapabilities, or that all the un-required capabilities are dropped for containers and SCCs. Is it the case that requiredDropCapabilities are not configured or configured correctly?

Inspect each SCC returned from running the following command: $ oc get scc Review each SCC and determine that allowHostNetwork is either completely disabled, or that allowHostNetwork is only enabled to a small set of containers and SCCs. Is it the case that allowHostNetwork is set to true or too many SCCs have allowHostNetwork enabled?

Inspect each SCC returned from running the following command: $ oc get scc Review each SCC and determine that allowHostPID is either completely disabled, or that allowHostPID is only enabled to a small set of containers and SCCs. Is it the case that allowHostPID is set to true or too many SCCs have allowHostPID enabled?

Inspect each SCC returned from running the following command: $ oc get scc Review each SCC and determine that allowPrivilegedContainer is either completely disabled, or that allowPrivilegedContainer is only enabled to a small set of containers and SCCs. Is it the case that allowPrivilegedContainer is set to true or too many SCCs have allowPrivilegedContainer enabled?

Inspect each SCC returned from running the following command: $ oc get scc Review each SCC and determine that allowPrivilegedContainer is either completely disabled, or that allowPrivilegedContainer is only enabled to a small set of containers and SCCs. Is it the case that allowPrivilegedContainer is set to true or too many SCCs have allowPrivilegedContainer enabled?

Inspect each SCC returned from running the following command: $ oc get scc Review each SCC and determine that only required capabilities are either completely added as a list entry under allowedCapabilities, or that all the un-required capabilities are dropped for containers and SCCs. Is it the case that allowed capabilities are not configured or limited in allowedCapabilities?

Run the following command on the kubelet node(s): $ sudo grep rotateCertificates /etc/kubernetes/kubernetes.conf The output should return true. Is it the case that the kubelet cannot rotate client certificate?
Run the following command on the kubelet node(s): $ sudo grep eventRecordQPS /etc/kubernetes/kubernetes.conf The output should return 0. Is it the case that events are limited?

Run the following command on the kubelet node(s): $ sudo grep RotateKubeletServerCertificate /etc/kubernetes/kubernetes.conf The output should return true. Is it the case that the kubelet cannot rotate server certificate?

Run the following command on the kubelet node(s): $ oc get configmap config -n openshift-kube-apiserver -ojson | jq -r '.data["config.yaml"]' | jq -r '.apiServerArguments["kubelet-client-certificate"]' The output should be 0. Verify that a client certificate is configured. Is it the case that the kubelet certificate is not configured?

Run the following command on the kubelet node(s): $ sudo grep streamingConnectionIdleTimeout /etc/kubernetes/kubelet.conf The output should return . Is it the case that the streaming connection timeouts are not disabled?

Run the following command on the kubelet node(s): $ oc get configmap config -n openshift-kube-apiserver -ojson | jq -r '.data["config.yaml"]' | jq -r '.apiServerArguments["kubelet-read-only-port"]' The output should be 0. Is it the case that the read-only port is not disabled?

Run the following command on the kubelet node(s): $ sudo grep makeIPTablesUtilChains /etc/kubernetes/kubelet.conf The output should return true. Is it the case that the kubelet cannot modify the firewall settings?

Run the following command on the kubelet node(s): $ sudo grep -A1 x509 /etc/kubernetes/kubernetes.conf The output should contain a configured certificate like /etc/kubernetes/kubelet-ca.crt. Is it the case that no client CA certificate has been configured?

Run the following command on the master node(s): $ sudo grep -A1 authorization /etc/kubernetes/kubernetes.conf Verify that the output is not set to mode: AlwaysAllow, or missing (defaults to mode: Webhook). Is it the case that <tt>authorization-mode</tt> is not configured to <tt>Webhook</tt>?

Run the following command on the kubelet node(s): $ sudo grep hostname-override /etc/origin/node/node-config.yaml The output should return no output. Is it the case that the hostname cannot be overrided?

Run the following command on the kubelet node(s): $ sudo grep tlsPrivateKeyFile /etc/kubernetes/kubernetes.conf Verify that a TLS private key is configured. Is it the case that the kubelet server key certificate is not configured?

Run the following command on the kubelet node(s): $ sudo grep RotateKubeletClientCertificate /etc/kubernetes/kubernetes.conf The output should return true. Is it the case that the kubelet cannot rotate client certificate?

Run the following command on the worker node(s): $ sudo grep -A1 anonymous /etc/kubernetes/kubernetes.conf The output should return enabled: false. Is it the case that <tt>anonymous</tt> authentication is not set to <tt>false</tt>?

To verify that APIPriorityAndFairness is enabled, run the following command: oc get kubeapiservers.operator.openshift.io cluster -o json | jq '.spec.observedConfig.apiServerArguments["feature-gates"]' The output should contain "APIPriorityAndFairness=true" Is it the case that <tt>.apiServerArguments["feature-gates"]</tt> does not include <tt>EventRateLimit</tt>?

To verify that the list of disabled admission plugins is empty, run the following command: $ oc -n openshift-kube-apiserver get configmap config -o json | jq -r '.data."config.yaml"' | jq '.apiServerArguments."disable-admission-plugins"' There should be no output. Is it the case that No admission plugins are disabled?

Run the following command on the master node(s): $ oc get configmap config -n openshift-kube-apiserver -ojson | jq -r '.data["config.yaml"]' | jq '.schedulerArguments["profiling"]' The output should return false. Is it the case that <tt>profiling</tt> is enabled and is set to value of <tt>true</tt>?

To verify that basic-auth-file is configured and enabled for the API server, run the following command: $ oc get configmap config -n openshift-kube-apiserver -ojson | jq -r '.data["config.yaml"]' | jq '.apiServerArguments["basic-auth-file"]' The output should return null. Is it the case that basic-auth-file is configured and enabled for the API server?

Run the following command on the master node(s): $ oc get configmap config -n openshift-kube-apiserver -ojson | jq -r '.data["config.yaml"]' | jq '.apiServerArguments["audit-log-path"]' Is it the case that <tt>audit-log-path</tt> does not contain a valid audit file path?

Run the following command on the master node(s): $ oc get configmap config -n openshift-apiserver -ojson | jq -r '.data["config.yaml"]' | jq '.apiServerArguments["audit-log-maxsize"]' The output should return a value of ["100"] or as appropriate. Is it the case that <tt>audit-log-maxsize</tt> is set to <tt>100</tt> or as appropriate?

Run the following command on the master node(s): $ oc get configmap config -n openshift-kube-apiserver -ojson | jq -r '.data["config.yaml"]' | jq -r '.apiServerArguments."etcd-keyfile"' The output should return a configured certificate key file. Is it the case that <tt>keyFile</tt> does not exist or is not configured to valid certificates?

Run the following command on the master node(s): $ oc get configmap config -n openshift-kube-apiserver -ojson | jq -r '.data["config.yaml"]' | jq '.apiServerArguments["request-timeout"]' The output should return 300. Is it the case that <tt>request-timeout</tt> is not set or is not set to an appropriate value?

Run the following command on the master node(s): $ oc get apiserver cluster -ojson | jq -r '.spec.encryption.type' The output should return aescdc as the encryption type. Is it the case that <tt>aescbc</tt> is not set as the encryption type for etcd.?

The SecurityContextDeny plugin should not be enabled in the list of enabled plugins in the apiserver configuration: $ oc -n openshift-kube-apiserver get configmap config -o json | jq -r '.data."config.yaml"' | jq '.apiServerArguments."enable-admission-plugins"' Is it the case that '<tt>enable-admission-plugins</tt>does not contain <tt>SecurityContextDeny</tt>'?

To verify that RBAC authorization mode is enabled, run the following command: $ oc get configmap config -n openshift-kube-apiserver -ojson | jq -r '.data["config.yaml"]' | grep '"authorization-mode":\[[^]]*"RBAC"' The output should show that the "authorization-mode" list contains the "RBAC" authorizer. Is it the case that The RBAC authorization mode is enabled?

To verify that the NamespaceLifecycle plugin is be enabled in the apiserver configuration, run: $ oc -n openshift-kube-apiserver get configmap config -o json | jq -r '.data."config.yaml"' | jq '.apiServerArguments."enable-admission-plugins"' Is it the case that API server config contains <tt>NamespaceLifecycle</tt>?

Run the following command on the master node(s): $ oc get configmap config -n openshift-kube-apiserver -ojson | jq -r '.data["config.yaml"]' | jq '.apiServerArguments["audit-log-maxsize"]' The output should return a value of ["100"] or as appropriate. Is it the case that <tt>audit-log-maxsize</tt> is set to <tt>100</tt> or as appropriate?

Run the following command: $ oc get configmap config -n openshift-kube-apiserver -ojson | jq -r '.data["config.yaml"]' | jq '.apiServerArguments' | grep "token-auth-file" The output should return no output. Is it the case that <tt>token-auth-file</tt> argument is configured?

The ServiceAccount plugin should be enabled in the list of enabled plugins in the apiserver configuration: $ oc -n openshift-kube-apiserver get configmap config -o json | jq -r '.data."config.yaml"' | jq '.apiServerArguments."enable-admission-plugins"' Is it the case that API server configuration contains <tt>ServiceAccount</tt>?

Run the following command on the master node(s): $ oc get configmap config -n openshift-apiserver -ojson | jq -r '.data["config.yaml"]' | jq '.apiServerArguments["audit-log-maxbackup"][0]' The output should return a value of 10 or as appropriate. Is it the case that <tt>audit-log-maxbackup</tt> is set to <tt>10</tt> or as appropriate?

Ensure that the NodeRestriction plugin is enabled in the list of enabled plugins in the apiserver configuration by running the following command: $ oc get configmap config -n openshift-kube-apiserver -ojson | jq -r '.data["config.yaml"]' | grep 'ServiceAccount' Is it the case that <tt>enable-admission-plugins</tt> does not contain <tt>NodeRestriction</tt>?

Run the following command: $ oc -n openshift-oauth-apiserver describe secret serving-cert Verify that the serving-cert for the openshift-apiserver is type kubernetes.io/tls and that returned Data includes tls.crt and tls.key. Is it the case that The openshift-apiserver serving-cert is not set to type <tt>kubernetes.io/tls</tt> and that returned Data does not include <tt>tls.crt</tt> and <tt>tls.key</tt>?

Run the following command: $ oc -n openshift-apiserver describe secret serving-cert Verify that the serving-cert for the openshift-apiserver is type kubernetes.io/tls and that returned Data includes tls.crt and tls.key. Is it the case that The openshift-apiserver serving-cert is not set to type <tt>kubernetes.io/tls</tt> and that returned Data does not include <tt>tls.crt</tt> and <tt>tls.key</tt>?

Run the following command: $ oc get configmap config -n openshift-kube-apiserver -ojson | jq -r '.data["config.yaml"]' | jq -r '.apiServerArguments."kubelet-certificate-authority"' The output should return a configured certificate. Is it the case that <tt>kubelet-certificate-authority</tt> is not set as appropriate for <tt>apiServerArguments</tt>?

Run the following command on the master node(s): $ oc get configmap config -n openshift-kube-apiserver -ojson | jq -r '.data["config.yaml"]' | jq -r .serviceAccountPublicKeyFiles The output should return configured certificate key file(s). Is it the case that serviceAccountPublicKeyFiles is not configured correctly?

To verify that Node authorization mode is enabled, run the following command: $ oc get configmap config -n openshift-kube-apiserver -ojson | jq -r '.data["config.yaml"]' | grep '"authorization-mode":\[[^]]*"Node"' The output should show that the "authorization-mode" list contains the "Node" authorizer. Is it the case that The Node authorization-mode is configured and enabled?

Run the following command on the master node(s): $ oc get configmap config -n openshift-kube-apiserver -ojson | jq -r '.data["config.yaml"]' | jq '.apiServerArguments["insecure-port"]' The output should return 0. Is it the case that <tt>insecure-port</tt> setting exists?

Run the following command: $ oc get configmap config -n openshift-kube-apiserver -ojson | jq -r '.data["config.yaml"]' | jq '.apiServerArguments["kubelet-client-certificate"]' The output should return /etc/kubernetes/static-pod-resources/secrets/kubelet-client/tls.crt Is it the case that <tt>kubelet-client-certificate</tt> is not set as appropriate in <tt>apiServerArguments:</tt>?

Run the following command on the master node(s): $ oc get configmap config -n openshift-kube-apiserver -ojson | jq -r '.data["config.yaml"]' | jq '.apiServerArguments["insecure-bind-address"]' The output should return null. Is it the case that insecure-bind-address is exists and has not been removed</tt>?

Run the following command on the master node(s): $ oc get configmap config -n openshift-kube-apiserver -ojson | jq -r '.data["config.yaml"]' | jq -r '.apiServerArguments."etcd-certfile"' The output should return a configured certificate file. Is it the case that <tt>etcd-certfile</tt> does not exist or is not configured to valid certificates?

Run the following command on the master node(s): $ oc get configmap config -n openshift-kube-apiserver -ojson | jq -r '.data["config.yaml"]' | jq '.apiServerArguments["anonymous-auth"]' The output should return false. Is it the case that <tt>anonymous-auth</tt> is not set to <tt>false</tt>?

The SecurityContextConstraint plugin should be enabled in the list of enabled plugins in the apiserver configuration: $ oc -n openshift-kube-apiserver get configmap config -o json | jq -r '.data."config.yaml"' | jq '.apiServerArguments."enable-admission-plugins"' Is it the case that the list of enabled admission plugins contains <tt>SecurityContextConstraint</tt>?

Run the following command on the master node(s): $ sudo grep -A4 AlwaysPullImages /etc/origin/master/master-config.yaml The output should return disable: false. Is it the case that <tt>admissionConfig</tt> does not contain <tt>AlwaysPullImages</tt>?

Run the following command on the master node(s): $ oc get configmap config -n openshift-kube-apiserver -ojson | jq -r '.data["config.yaml"]' | jq -r '.apiServerArguments."tls-private-key-file"' The output should return /etc/kubernetes/static-pod-certs/secrets/service-network-serving-certkey/tls.key Is it the case that <tt>tls-private-key-file</tt> is not set as appropriate for <tt>apiServerArguments</tt>?

Run the following command on the master node(s): $ oc get configmap config -n openshift-kube-apiserver -o json | \ jq -r '.data["config.yaml"]' | \ jq -r '.apiServerArguments["service-account-lookup"]' The output should return true. Is it the case that API server argument <tt>--service-account-lookup</tt> contains <tt>true</tt>?

Run the following command on the master node(s): $ sudo grep -A1 authorization-mode /etc/origin/master/master-config.yaml Verify that there is no output, or the output is set to Webhook. Is it the case that <tt>authorization-mode</tt> is not configured to <tt>Webhook</tt>?

Run the following command on the master node(s): $ oc get configmap config -n openshift-kube-apiserver -ojson | jq -r '.data["config.yaml"]' | jq '.apiServerArguments["audit-log-maxbackup"][0]' The output should return a value of 10 or as appropriate. Is it the case that <tt>audit-log-maxbackup</tt> is set to <tt>10</tt> or as appropriate?

Run the following command: $ oc get configmap config -n openshift-kube-apiserver -ojson | jq -r '.data["config.yaml"]' | jq '.apiServerArguments["kubelet-client-key"]' The output should return /etc/kubernetes/static-pod-resources/secrets/kubelet-client/tls.key Is it the case that <tt>kubelet-client-key</tt> is not set as appropriate in <tt>apiServerArguments:</tt>?

To verify that the AlwaysAllow admission control plugin is not set, run the following command: $ oc -n openshift-kube-apiserver get configmap config -o json | jq -r '.data."config.yaml"' | jq '.apiServerArguments."enable-admission-plugins"' The output should return no output. Is it the case that <tt>AlwaysAllow</tt> admission control plugin is not set?

Run the following command on the master node(s): $ oc get configmap config -n openshift-kube-apiserver -ojson | jq -r '.data["config.yaml"]' | jq '.auditConfig["maximumFileRetentionDays"]' The output should return a value of 30 or as appropriate. Is it the case that <tt>maximumFileRetentionDays</tt> is set less than <tt>30</tt> or as appropriate?

Run the following commands: oc get flowschema and inspect the FlowSchema objects. Make sure that at least the catch-all object exists by calling: oc describe flowschema catch-all Is it the case that A FlowSchema object <tt>catch-all</tt> exists?

Run the following command on the master node(s): $ oc get secrets encryption-config -n openshift-kube-apiserver -o json | jq -r '.data["encryption-config"]' | base64 -d | jq -r '.resources' Verify that the aescbc encryption provider is used for all the desired resources. Is it the case that <tt>aescbc</tt> is not configured as the encryption provider?

Run the following command on the master node(s): $ oc get configmap config -n openshift-kube-apiserver -ojson | jq -r '.data["config.yaml"]' | jq '.servingInfo["cipherSuites"]' Verify that the output is similar to:
"TLS_ECDHE_ECDSA_WITH_AES_128_GCM_SHA256", "TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_128_GCM_SHA256", "TLS_ECDHE_ECDSA_WITH_AES_256_GCM_SHA384", "TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_256_GCM_SHA384", "TLS_ECDHE_ECDSA_WITH_CHACHA20_POLY1305", "TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_CHACHA20_POLY1305"
Is it the case that <tt>cipherSuites</tt> does not contain TLS_ECDHE_ECDSA_WITH_AES_128_GCM_SHA256,TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_128_GCM_SHA256,TLS_ECDHE_ECDSA_WITH_CHACHA20_POLY1305,TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_256_GCM_SHA384,TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_CHACHA20_POLY1305,TLS_ECDHE_ECDSA_WITH_AES_256_GCM_SHA384,TLS_RSA_WITH_AES_256_GCM_SHA384,TLS_RSA_WITH_AES_128_GCM_SHA256 from servingInfo?

To verify that the Node authorization mode is be configured and enabled in the apiserver configuration, run: $ oc get configmap config -n openshift-kube-apiserver -ojson | jq -r '.data["config.yaml"]' | grep '"authorization-mode":\[[^]]*"AlwaysAllow"' The output should be empty - the "authorization-mode" list does NOT contain the "AlwaysAllow" authorizer. Is it the case that The Node authorization-mode is configured and enabled?

Run the following command on the master node(s): $ oc get configmap config -n openshift-kube-apiserver -ojson | jq -r '.data["config.yaml"]' | jq '.apiServerArguments["etcd-cafile"]' The output should return a configured CA certificate for ETCD. Is it the case that <tt>etcd-cafile</tt> is not set as appropriate for <tt>apiServerArguments</tt>?
This is for testing Is it the case that This is for testing?

Run the following command on the master node(s): $ oc get configmap config -n openshift-kube-apiserver -ojson | jq -r '.data["config.yaml"]' | jq '.apiServerArguments["client-ca-file"]' The output should return a configured TLS CA certificate file. Is it the case that <tt>client-ca-file</tt> is not set as appropriate for <tt>apiServerArguments</tt>?

Run the following command: $ oc get configmap config -n openshift-kube-apiserver -ojson | jq -r '.data["config.yaml"]' | jq -r '.apiServerArguments."tls-cert-file"' The output should return /etc/kubernetes/static-pod-certs/secrets/service-network-serving-certkey/tls.crt Is it the case that <tt>tls-cert-file</tt> is not set as appropriate for <tt>apiServerArguments</tt>?

To check the permissions of /var/lib/kubelet/kubeconfig, run the command: $ ls -l /var/lib/kubelet/kubeconfig If properly configured, the output should indicate the following permissions: -rw------- Is it the case that /var/lib/kubelet/kubeconfig has unix mode -rw-------?

To check the ownership of /etc/systemd/system/kubelet.service, run the command: $ ls -lL /etc/systemd/system/kubelet.service If properly configured, the output should indicate the following owner: root Is it the case that '/etc/systemd/system/kubelet.service has owner root'?

To check the permissions of /etc/kubernetes/kubelet-ca.crt, run the command: $ ls -l /etc/kubernetes/kubelet-ca.crt If properly configured, the output should indicate the following permissions: -rw-r--r-- Is it the case that /etc/kubernetes/kubelet-ca.crt has unix mode -rw-r--r--?

To check the group ownership of /config/kube-proxy-config.yaml, run the command: $ ls -lL /config/kube-proxy-config.yaml If properly configured, the output should indicate the following group-owner: root Is it the case that /config/kube-proxy-config.yaml has group owner root?

Run the following command on the master node(s): $ oc get configmap config -n openshift-apiserver -ojson | jq -r '.data["config.yaml"]' | jq '.apiServerArguments["audit-log-path"]' The output should return a valid audit log path. Is it the case that <tt>audit-log-path</tt> does not contain a valid audit file path?

Run the following command: oc get -nopenshift-etcd cm etcd-pod -oyaml | grep "\-\-peer-client-cert-auth=" The parameter should be set to true. Is it the case that the etcd peer client certificate authentication is not configured?

Run the following command on the master node(s): $ oc get cm/etcd-pod -n openshift-etcd -o yaml The etcd pod configuration contained in the configmap should not contain the --auto-tls=true flag. Is it the case that the etcd is using self-signed certificates?

Run the following command: oc get -nopenshift-etcd cm etcd-pod -oyaml | grep "\-\-cert-file=/etc/kubernetes/static-pod-certs/secrets/etcd-all-serving/etcd-serving-NODE_NAME.crt" Verify that there is a certificate configured. Is it the case that the etcd client certificate is not configured?

Run the following command: oc get -nopenshift-etcd cm etcd-pod -oyaml | grep "\-\-client-cert-auth=" The parameter should be set to true. Is it the case that the etcd client certificate authentication is not configured?

Run the following command: oc get -nopenshift-etcd cm etcd-pod -oyaml | grep "\-\-peer-cert-file=/etc/kubernetes/static-pod-certs/secrets/etcd-all-peer/etcd-peer-NODE_NAME.crt" Verify that there is a certificate configured. Is it the case that the etcd peer client certificate is not configured?

Run the following command on the master node(s): $ grep ETCD_TRUSTED_CA_FILE /etc/etcd/etcd.conf Inspect the certificate file that is returned and verify that it does not match the OpenShift CA certificate. Is it the case that the etcd CA certificate is not unique?

Run the following command: oc get -nopenshift-etcd cm etcd-pod -oyaml | grep "\-\-key-file=/etc/kubernetes/static-pod-certs/secrets/etcd-all-serving/etcd-serving-NODE_NAME.key" Verify that there is a certificate configured. Is it the case that the etcd client key file is not configured?

Run the following command: oc get -nopenshift-etcd cm etcd-pod -oyaml | grep "\-\-peer-key-file=/etc/kubernetes/static-pod-certs/secrets/etcd-all-peer/etcd-peer-NODE_NAME.key" Verify that there is a certificate configured. Is it the case that the etcd peer client key file is not configured?

Run the following command on the master node(s): $ oc get cm/etcd-pod -n openshift-etcd -o yaml The etcd pod configuration contained in the configmap should not contain the --peer-auto-tls=true flag. Is it the case that the etcd is using peer self-signed certificates?

oval-def:criterion.comment: In the YAML/JSON file '/api/v1/namespaces/openshift-etcd/configmaps/etcd-pod' at path '.data['pod.yaml']' all

oval-def:criterion.comment: In the YAML/JSON file '/api/v1/namespaces/openshift-etcd/configmaps/etcd-pod' at path '.data['pod.yaml']' all

oval-def:metadata.oval-def:title: Disable Anonymous Authentication to the Kubelet
oval-def:metadata.oval-def:description: In the YAML/JSON file '/etc/kubernetes/kubelet.conf' at path '.authentication.anonymous.enabled' all: value equals 'false'

oval-def:criterion.comment: In the YAML/JSON file '/etc/kubernetes/kubelet.conf' at path '.authentication.anonymous.enabled' all

oval-def:metadata.oval-def:title: Ensure authorization is set to Webhook
oval-def:metadata.oval-def:description: In the YAML/JSON file '/etc/kubernetes/kubelet.conf' at path '.authorization.mode' all: value equals 'AlwaysAllow'

oval-def:criterion.comment: In the YAML/JSON file '/etc/kubernetes/kubelet.conf' at path '.authorization.mode' all

oval-def:metadata.oval-def:title: kubelet - Configure the Client CA Certificate
oval-def:metadata.oval-def:description: In the YAML/JSON file '/etc/kubernetes/kubelet.conf' at path '.authentication.x509.clientCAFile' all: value equals '/etc/kubernetes/kubelet-ca.crt'

oval-def:criterion.comment: In the YAML/JSON file '/etc/kubernetes/kubelet.conf' at path '.authentication.x509.clientCAFile' all

oval-def:metadata.oval-def:title: Ensure That The kubelet Client Certificate Is Correctly Set
oval-def:metadata.oval-def:description: In the YAML/JSON file '/api/v1/namespaces/openshift-kube-apiserver/configmaps/config' at path '.data['config.yaml']' all: value equals '"kubelet-client-certificate":\["/etc/kubernetes/static-pod-resources/secrets/kubelet-client/tls.crt"\]'

oval-def:criterion.comment: In the YAML/JSON file '/api/v1/namespaces/openshift-kube-apiserver/configmaps/config' at path '.data['config.yaml']' all
Make sure that the file '/api/v1/namespaces/openshift-kube-apiserver/configmaps/config' exists.

oval-def:metadata.oval-def:title: kubelet - Disable the Read-Only Port
oval-def:metadata.oval-def:description: In the YAML/JSON file '/api/v1/namespaces/openshift-kube-apiserver/configmaps/config' at path '.data['config.yaml']' all: value equals '.*kubelet-read-only-port"\:\["0"\].*'

oval-def:criterion.comment: In the YAML/JSON file '/api/v1/namespaces/openshift-kube-apiserver/configmaps/config' at path '.data['config.yaml']' all
Make sure that the file '/api/v1/namespaces/openshift-kube-apiserver/configmaps/config' exists.

oval-def:metadata.oval-def:title: kubelet - Enable Certificate Rotation
oval-def:metadata.oval-def:description: In the YAML/JSON file '/etc/kubernetes/kubelet.conf' at path '.rotateCertificates' all: value equals 'true'

oval-def:criterion.comment: In the YAML/JSON file '/etc/kubernetes/kubelet.conf' at path '.rotateCertificates' all

oval-def:metadata.oval-def:title: kubelet - Enable Client Certificate Rotation
oval-def:metadata.oval-def:description: In the YAML/JSON file '/etc/kubernetes/kubelet.conf' at path '.featureGates.RotateKubeletClientCertificate' all: value equals 'false'

oval-def:criterion.comment: In the YAML/JSON file '/etc/kubernetes/kubelet.conf' at path '.featureGates.RotateKubeletClientCertificate' all

oval-def:metadata.oval-def:title: kubelet - Allow Automatic Firewall Configuration
oval-def:metadata.oval-def:description: In the YAML/JSON file '/etc/kubernetes/kubelet.conf' at path '.makeIPTablesUtilChains' all: value equals 'false'

oval-def:criterion.comment: In the YAML/JSON file '/etc/kubernetes/kubelet.conf' at path '.makeIPTablesUtilChains' all

oval-def:metadata.oval-def:title: kubelet - Enable Server Certificate Rotation
oval-def:metadata.oval-def:description: In the YAML/JSON file '/etc/kubernetes/kubelet.conf' at path '.featureGates.RotateKubeletServerCertificate' all: value equals 'true'

oval-def:criterion.comment: In the YAML/JSON file '/etc/kubernetes/kubelet.conf' at path '.featureGates.RotateKubeletServerCertificate' all

oval-def:metadata.oval-def:title: kubelet - Do Not Disable Streaming Timeouts

xccdf-1.2:Benchmark.xccdf-1.2:title: Guide to the Secure Configuration of Red Hat OpenShift Container Platform 4
xccdf-1.2:Benchmark.xccdf-1.2:description:
This guide presents a catalog of security-relevant configuration settings for Red Hat OpenShift Container Platform 4. It is a rendering of content structured in the eXtensible Configuration Checklist Description Format (XCCDF) in order to support security automation. The SCAP content is is available in the scap-security-guide package which is developed at
https://www.open-scap.org/security-policies/scap-security-guide.
Providing system administrators with such guidance informs them how to securely configure systems under their control in a variety of network roles. Policy makers and baseline creators can use this catalog of settings, with its associated references to higher-level security control catalogs, in order to assist them in security baseline creation. This guide is a catalog, not a checklist, and satisfaction of every item is not likely to be possible or sensible in many operational scenarios. However, the XCCDF format enables granular selection and adjustment of settings, and their association with OVAL and OCIL content provides an automated checking capability. Transformations of this document, and its associated automated checking content, are capable of providing baselines that meet a diverse set of policy objectives. Some example XCCDF Profiles, which are selections of items that form checklists and can be used as baselines, are available with this guide. They can be processed, in an automated fashion, with tools that support the Security Content Automation Protocol (SCAP). The NIST National Checklist Program (NCP), which provides required settings for the United States Government, is one example of a baseline created from this guidance.
xccdf-1.2:Benchmark.xccdf-1.2:notice: Do not attempt to implement any of the settings in this guide without first testing them in a non-operational environment. The creators of this guidance assume no responsibility whatsoever for its use by other parties, and makes no guarantees, expressed or implied, about its quality, reliability, or any other characteristic.
xccdf-1.2:Benchmark.xccdf-1.2:rear-matter: Red Hat and Red Hat Enterprise Linux are either registered trademarks or trademarks of Red Hat, Inc. in the United States and other countries. All other names are registered trademarks or trademarks of their respective companies.

xccdf-1.2:Group.xccdf-1.2:title: Introduction
xccdf-1.2:Group.xccdf-1.2:description: The purpose of this guidance is to provide security configuration recommendations and baselines for Red Hat OpenShift Container Platform 4. The guide is intended for system and/or application administrators. Readers are assumed to possess basic system administration skills for the application's operating systems, as well as some familiarity with the product's documentation and administration conventions. Some instructions within this guide are complex. All directions should be followed completely and with understanding of their effects in order to avoid serious adverse effects on the system and its security.

xccdf-1.2:Group.xccdf-1.2:title: How to Use This Guide
xccdf-1.2:Group.xccdf-1.2:description: Readers should heed the following points when using the guide.

xccdf-1.2:Group.xccdf-1.2:title: Root Shell Environment Assumed
xccdf-1.2:Group.xccdf-1.2:description: Most of the actions listed in this document are written with the assumption that they will be executed by the root user running the /bin/bash shell. Commands preceded with a hash mark (#) assume that the administrator will execute the commands as root, i.e. apply the command via sudo whenever possible, or use su to gain root privileges if sudo cannot be used. Commands which can be executed as a non-root user are are preceded by a dollar sign ($) prompt.

xccdf-1.2:Group.xccdf-1.2:title: Reboot Required
xccdf-1.2:Group.xccdf-1.2:description: A system or service reboot is implicitly required after some actions in order to complete the reconfiguration of the system. In many cases, the changes will not take effect until a reboot is performed. In order to ensure that changes are applied properly and to test functionality, always reboot the system after applying a set of recommendations from this guide.

xccdf-1.2:Group.xccdf-1.2:title: Test in Non-Production Environment
xccdf-1.2:Group.xccdf-1.2:description: This guidance should always be tested in a non-production environment before deployment. This test environment should simulate the setup in which the system will be deployed as closely as possible.

xccdf-1.2:Group.xccdf-1.2:title: Formatting Conventions
xccdf-1.2:Group.xccdf-1.2:description: Commands intended for shell execution, as well as configuration file text, are featured in a monospace font. Italics are used to indicate instances where the system administrator must substitute the appropriate information into a command or configuration file.

xccdf-1.2:Group.xccdf-1.2:title: Read Sections Completely and in Order
xccdf-1.2:Group.xccdf-1.2:description: Each section may build on information and recommendations discussed in prior sections. Each section should be read and understood completely; instructions should never be blindly applied. Relevant discussion may occur after instructions for an action.

xccdf-1.2:Group.xccdf-1.2:title: General Principles
xccdf-1.2:Group.xccdf-1.2:description: The following general principles motivate much of the advice in this guide and should also influence any configuration decisions that are not explicitly covered.

xccdf-1.2:Group.xccdf-1.2:title: Encrypt Transmitted Data Whenever Possible
xccdf-1.2:Group.xccdf-1.2:description: Data transmitted over a network, whether wired or wireless, is susceptible to passive monitoring. Whenever practical solutions for encrypting such data exist, they should be applied. Even if data is expected to be transmitted only over a local network, it should still be encrypted. Encrypting authentication data, such as passwords, is particularly important. Networks of Red Hat OpenShift Container Platform 4 machines can and should be configured so that no unencrypted authentication data is ever transmitted between machines.

xccdf-1.2:Group.xccdf-1.2:title: Configure Security Tools to Improve System Robustness
xccdf-1.2:Group.xccdf-1.2:description: Several tools exist which can be effectively used to improve a system's resistance to and detection of unknown attacks. These tools can improve robustness against attack at the cost of relatively little configuration effort.

xccdf-1.2:Group.xccdf-1.2:title: Run Different Network Services on Separate Systems
xccdf-1.2:Group.xccdf-1.2:description: Whenever possible, a server should be dedicated to serving exactly one network service. This limits the number of other services that can be compromised in the event that an attacker is able to successfully exploit a software flaw in one network service.

xccdf-1.2:Group.xccdf-1.2:title: Least Privilege
xccdf-1.2:Group.xccdf-1.2:description: Grant the least privilege necessary for user accounts and software to perform tasks. For example, sudo can be implemented to limit authorization to super user accounts on the system only to designated personnel. Another example is to limit logins on server systems to only those administrators who need to log into them in order to perform administration tasks.

xccdf-1.2:Group.xccdf-1.2:title: OpenShift Settings
xccdf-1.2:Group.xccdf-1.2:description:
Each section of this configuration guide includes information about the default configuration of an OpenShift cluster and a set of recommendations for hardening the configuration. For each hardening recommendation, information on how to implement the control and/or how to verify or audit the control is provided. In some cases, remediation information is also provided.
Many of the settings in the hardening guide are in place by default. The audit information for these settings is provided in order to verify that the cluster admininstrator has not made changes that would be less secure than the OpenShift defaults. A small number of items require configuration.
Finally, there are some recommendations that require decisions by the system operator, such as audit log size, retention, and related settings.

xccdf-1.2:Value.xccdf-1.2:title: Root of files obtained from OCP nodes
xccdf-1.2:Value.xccdf-1.2:description: When scanning OpenShift clusters, some settings are not exposed as files. In the case that they are exported from the cluster (typically as yaml files), this variable determines the directory where they will end up.

xccdf-1.2:Group.xccdf-1.2:title: OpenShift - Account and Access Control
xccdf-1.2:Group.xccdf-1.2:description: In traditional Unix security, if an attacker gains shell access to a certain login account, they can perform any action or access any file to which that account has access. The same idea applies to cloud technology such as OpenShift. Therefore, making it more difficult for unauthorized people to gain shell access to accounts, particularly to privileged accounts, is a necessary part of securing a system. This section introduces mechanisms for restricting access to accounts under OpenShift.

xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:title: Ensure Usage of Unique Service Accounts
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:description: Using the default service account prevents accurate application rights review and audit tracing. For each namespace, create a new and unique service account with the following command: $ oc create sa service_account_name> where service_account_name> is the name of a service account that is needed in the project namespace.
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:rationale: Kubernetes provides a default service account which is used by cluster workloads where no specific service account is assigned to the pod. Where access to the Kubernetes API from a pod is required, a specific service account should be created for that pod, and rights granted to that service account. This increases auditability of service account rights and access making it easier and more accurate to trace potential malicious behaviors to a specific service account and project.

xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:title: Restrict Automounting of Service Account Tokens
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:description: Service accounts tokens should not be mounted in pods except where the workload running in the pod explicitly needs to communicate with the API server. To ensure pods do not automatically mount tokens, set automountServiceAccountToken to false.
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:rationale: Mounting service account tokens inside pods can provide an avenue for privilege escalation attacks where an attacker is able to compromise a single pod in the cluster.

xccdf-1.2:Group.xccdf-1.2:title: OpenShift - Registry Security Practices
xccdf-1.2:Group.xccdf-1.2:description: Contains evaluations for OpenShift registry security practices, and cluster-wide registry configuration.

xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:title: Allowed registries are configured
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:description:
The configuration registrySources.allowedRegistries determines the permitted registries that the OpenShift container runtime can access for builds and pods. This configuration setting ensures that all registries other than those specified are blocked.
You can set the allowed repositories by applying the following manifest using oc patch, e.g. if you save the following snippet to /tmp/allowed-registries-patch.yaml
spec: registrySources: allowedRegistries: - my-trusted-registry.internal.example.com you would call oc patch image.config.openshift.io cluster --patch="$(cat /tmp/allowed-registries-patch.yaml)" --type=merge
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:warning: This rule's check operates on the cluster configuration dump. Therefore, you need to use a tool that can query the OCP API, retreive the /apis/config.openshift.io/v1/images/cluster API endpoint to the local /apis/config.openshift.io/v1/images/cluster file.
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:rationale: Allowed registries should be configured to restrict the registries that the OpenShift container runtime can access, and all other registries should be blocked.

xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:title: Allowed registries for import are configured
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:description:
The configuration allowedRegistriesForImport limits the container image registries from which normal users may import images. This is important to control, as a user who can stand up a malicious registry can then import content which claims to include the SHAs of legimitate content layers. You can set the allowed repositories for import by applying the following manifest using oc patch, e.g. if you save the following snippet to /tmp/allowed-import-registries-patch.yaml
spec: allowedRegistriesForImport: - domainName: my-trusted-registry.internal.example.com insecure: false you would call oc patch image.config.openshift.io cluster --patch="$(cat /tmp/allowed-import-registries-patch.yaml)" --type=merge
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:warning: This rule's check operates on the cluster configuration dump. Therefore, you need to use a tool that can query the OCP API, retreive the /apis/config.openshift.io/v1/images/cluster API endpoint to the local /apis/config.openshift.io/v1/images/cluster file.
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:rationale: Allowed registries for import should be specified to limit the registries from which users may import images.

xccdf-1.2:Group.xccdf-1.2:title: OpenShift Controller Settings
xccdf-1.2:Group.xccdf-1.2:description: This section contains recommendations for the kube-controller-manager configuration

xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:title: Configure the Service Account Certificate Authority Key for the Controller Manager
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:description:
To ensure the API Server utilizes its own key pair, set the masterCA parameter to the public key file for service accounts in the openshift-kube-controller-manager configmap on the master node(s):
"extendedArguments": { ... "root-ca-file": [ "/etc/kubernetes/static-pod-resources/configmaps/serviceaccount-ca/ca-bundle.crt" ], ...
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:warning: This rule's check operates on the cluster configuration dump. Therefore, you need to use a tool that can query the OCP API, retreive the /api/v1/namespaces/openshift-kube-controller-manager/configmaps/config API endpoint to the local /api/v1/namespaces/openshift-kube-controller-manager/configmaps/config file.
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:rationale: Service accounts authenticate to the API using tokens signed by a private RSA key. The authentication layer verifies the signature using a matching public RSA key. Configuring the certificate authority file ensures that the API server's signing certificates are validated.

xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:title: Ensure that use-service-account-credentials is enabled
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:description:
To ensure individual service account credentials are used, set the use-service-account-credentials option to true in the openshift-kube-controller-manager configmap on the master node(s):
"extendedArguments": { ... "use-service-account-credentials": [ "true" ], ...
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:warning: This rule's check operates on the cluster configuration dump. Therefore, you need to use a tool that can query the OCP API, retreive the /api/v1/namespaces/openshift-kube-controller-manager/configmaps/config API endpoint to the local /api/v1/namespaces/openshift-kube-controller-manager/configmaps/config file.
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:rationale: The controller manager creates a service account per controller in kube-system namespace, generates an API token and credentials for it, then builds a dedicated API client with that service account credential for each controller loop to use. Setting the use-service-account-credentials to true runs each control loop within the contoller manager using a separate service account credential. When used in combination with RBAC, this ensures that the control loops run with the minimum permissions required to perform their intended tasks.

xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:title: Ensure Controller secure-port argument is set
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:description:
To ensure the Controller Manager service is bound to secure loopback address using a secure port, set the RotateKubeletServerCertificate option to true in the openshift-kube-controller-manager configmap on the master node(s):
"extendedArguments": { ... "secure-port": ["10257"], ...
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:warning: This rule's check operates on the cluster configuration dump. Therefore, you need to use a tool that can query the OCP API, retreive the /api/v1/namespaces/openshift-kube-controller-manager/configmaps/config API endpoint to the local /api/v1/namespaces/openshift-kube-controller-manager/configmaps/config file.
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:rationale: The Controller Manager API service is used for health and metrics information and is available without authentication or encryption. As such, it should only be bound to a localhost interface to minimize the cluster's attack surface.

xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:title: Configure the Service Account Private Key for the Controller Manager
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:description:
To ensure the API Server utilizes its own key pair, set the privateKeyFile parameter to the public key file for service accounts in the openshift-kube-controller-manager configmap on the master node(s):
"extendedArguments": { ... "service-account-private-key-file": [ "/etc/kubernetes/static-pod-resources/secrets/service-account-private-key/service-account.key" ], ...
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:warning: This rule's check operates on the cluster configuration dump. Therefore, you need to use a tool that can query the OCP API, retreive the /api/v1/namespaces/openshift-kube-controller-manager/configmaps/config API endpoint to the local /api/v1/namespaces/openshift-kube-controller-manager/configmaps/config file.
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:rationale: By default if no private key file is specified to the API Server, the API Server uses the private key from the TLS serving certificate to verify service account tokens. To ensure that the keys for service account tokens could be rotated as needed, a separate public/private key pair should be used for signing service account tokens.

xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:title: Ensure Controller insecure port argument is unset
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:description:
To ensure the Controller Manager service is bound to secure loopback address and a secure port, set the RotateKubeletServerCertificate option to true in the openshift-kube-controller-manager configmap on the master node(s):
"extendedArguments": { ... "port": ["0"], ...
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:warning: This rule's check operates on the cluster configuration dump. Therefore, you need to use a tool that can query the OCP API, retreive the /api/v1/namespaces/openshift-kube-controller-manager/configmaps/config API endpoint to the local /api/v1/namespaces/openshift-kube-controller-manager/configmaps/config file.
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:rationale: The Controller Manager API service is used for health and metrics information and is available without authentication or encryption. As such, it should only be bound to a localhost interface to minimize the cluster's attack surface.

xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:title: Enable terminated-pod-gc-threshold for the Controller Manager
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:description:
To ensure the garbage collector is activated upon pod termination, set the terminated-pod-gc-threshold option to 12500 or a value greater than zeroin the openshift-kube-controller-manager configmap on the master node(s):
"extendedArguments": { ... "terminated-pod-gc-threshold": [ "12500" ], ...
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:rationale: Garbage collection is important to ensure sufficient resource availability and avoiding degraded performance and availability. In the worst case, the system might crash or just be unusable for a long period of time. The default setting for garbage collection is 12,500 terminated pods which might be to high for your system to sustain. Based on your system resources and tests, choose an appropriate threshold value to activate garbage collection.

xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:title: Ensure that the RotateKubeletServerCertificate argument is set
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:description:
To enforce kublet server certificate rotation on the Controller Manager, set the RotateKubeletServerCertificate option to true in the openshift-kube-controller-manager configmap on the master node(s):
"extendedArguments": { ... "feature-gates": [ ... "RotateKubeletServerCertificate=true", ... ...
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:warning: This rule's check operates on the cluster configuration dump. Therefore, you need to use a tool that can query the OCP API, retreive the /api/v1/namespaces/openshift-kube-controller-manager/configmaps/config API endpoint to the local /api/v1/namespaces/openshift-kube-controller-manager/configmaps/config file.

This recommendation only applies if you let kubelets get their certificates from the API Server. In case your certificates come from an outside Certificate Authority/tool (e.g. Vault) then you need to take care of rotation yourself
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:rationale: Enabling kubelet certificate rotation causes the kubelet to both request a serving certificate after bootstrapping its client credentials and rotate the certificate as its existing credentials expire. This automated periodic rotation ensures that there are no downtimes due to expired certificates and thus addressing the availability in the C/I/A security triad.

xccdf-1.2:Group.xccdf-1.2:title: Network Configuration and Firewalls
xccdf-1.2:Group.xccdf-1.2:description:
Most systems must be connected to a network of some sort, and this brings with it the substantial risk of network attack. This section discusses the security impact of decisions about networking which must be made when configuring a system.
This section also discusses firewalls, network access controls, and other network security frameworks, which allow system-level rules to be written that can limit an attackers' ability to connect to your system. These rules can specify that network traffic should be allowed or denied from certain IP addresses, hosts, and networks. The rules can also specify which of the system's network services are available to particular hosts or networks.

xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:title: Ensure Project Namespaces Use Network Policies
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:description: Network policies should be configured for each project to isolate traffic on the network.
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:rationale: Running different applications on the same Kubernetes cluster creates a risk of one compromised application attacking a neighboring application. Network segmentation is important to ensure that containers can communicate only with those they are supposed to. When a network policy is introduced to a given namespace, all traffic not allowed by the policy is denied. However, if there are no network policies in a namespace all traffic will be allowed into and out of the pods in that namespace.

xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:title: Ensure Network Policies are Configured
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:description: OpenShift supports Kubernetes NetworkPolicy using a Kubernetes Container Network Interface (CNI) plug-in. The Kubernetes NetworkPolicy plugin is preferred because Kubernetes Network Policies provide more granular control.
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:rationale: Properly configured network policies ensure traffic between OpenShift tenants is isolated.

xccdf-1.2:Group.xccdf-1.2:title: Role-based Acess Control
xccdf-1.2:Group.xccdf-1.2:description:
Role-based access control (RBAC) objects determine whether a user is allowed to perform a given action within a project.
Cluster administrators can use the cluster roles and bindings to control who has various access levels to the OpenShift Container Platform platform itself and all projects.
Developers can use local roles and bindings to control who has access to their projects. Note that authorization is a separate step from authentication, which is more about determining the identity of who is taking the action.

xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:title: Minimize Wildcard Usage in Cluster and Local Roles
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:description: Kubernetes Cluster and Local Roles provide access to resources based on sets of objects and actions that can be taken on those objects. It is possible to set either of these using a wildcard * which matches all items. This violates the principle of least privilege and leaves a cluster in a more vulnerable state to privilege abuse.
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:rationale: The principle of least privilege recommends that users are provided only the access required for their role and nothing more. The use of wildcard rights grants is likely to provide excessive rights to the Kubernetes API.

xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:title: Limit Access to Kubernetes Secrets
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:description: The Kubernetes API stores secrets, which may be service account tokens for the Kubernetes API or credentials used by workloads in the cluster. Access to these secrets should be restricted to the smallest possible group of users to reduce the risk of privilege escalation. To restict users from secrets, remove get, list, and watch access to unauthorized users to secret objects in the cluster.
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:rationale: Inappropriate access to secrets stored within the Kubernetes cluster can allow for an attacker to gain additional access to the Kubernetes cluster or external resources whose credentials are stored as secrets.

xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:title: Profiling is protected by RBAC
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:description: Ensure that the cluster-debugger cluster role includes the /debug/pprof resource URL. This demonstrates that profiling is protected by RBAC, with a specific cluster role to allow access.
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:warning: This rule's check operates on the cluster configuration dump. Therefore, you need to use a tool that can query the OCP API, retreive the /apis/rbac.authorization.k8s.io/v1/clusterroles/cluster-debugger API endpoint to the local /apis/rbac.authorization.k8s.io/v1/clusterroles/cluster-debugger file.
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:rationale: Profiling allows for the identification of specific performance bottlenecks. It generates a significant amount of program data that could potentially be exploited to uncover system and program details. If you are not experiencing any bottlenecks and do not need the profiler for troubleshooting purposes, it is recommended to turn it off to reduce the potential attack surface. To ensure the collected data is not exploited, profiling endpoints are secured via RBAC (see cluster-debugger role). By default, the profiling endpoints are accessible only by users bound to cluster-admin or cluster-debugger role. Profiling can not be disabled.

xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:title: Limit Access to Cluster Admin
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:description: The cluster-admin role provides superuser or privilaged access to an OpenShift cluster. As such, it should be limited to a small subset of trusted users. To remove users from the cluster-admin role, run the following command where username is the name of the user to remove: $ oc adm policy remove-cluster-role-from-user cluster-admin username
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:rationale: The RBAC role cluster-admin provides superuser or privilaged access to an OpenShift cluster. As such, it should be limited to a small subset of trusted users.

xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:title: Minimize Access to Pod Creation
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:description: The ability to create pods in a namespace can provide a number of opportunities for privilege escalation. Where applicable, remove create access to pod objects in the cluster.
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:rationale: The ability to create pods in a cluster opens up the cluster for privilege escalation.

xccdf-1.2:Group.xccdf-1.2:title: Security Context Constraints (SCC)
xccdf-1.2:Group.xccdf-1.2:description: Similar to the way that RBAC resources control user access, administrators can use Security Context Constraints (SCCs) to control permissions for pods. These permissions include actions that a pod, a collection of containers, can perform and what resources it can access. You can use SCCs to define a set of conditions that a pod must run with in order to be accepted into the system.

xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:title: Limit Containers Ability to Escalate Privileges
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:description: Containers should be limited to only the privileges required to run and should not be allowed to escalate their privileges. To prevent containers from escalating privileges, the appropriate Security Context Constraints (SCCs) should set allowPrivilegeEscalation to false.
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:warning: This rule's check operates on the cluster configuration dump. Therefore, you need to use a tool that can query the OCP API, retreive the /apis/security.openshift.io/v1/securitycontextconstraints API endpoint to the local /apis/security.openshift.io/v1/securitycontextconstraints file.
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:rationale: Privileged containers have access to more of the Linux Kernel capabilities and devices. If a privileged container were compromised, an attacker would have full access to the container and host.

xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:title: Limit Use of the CAP_NET_RAW
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:description: Containers should not enable more capabilites than needed as this opens the door for malicious use. CAP_NET_RAW enables a container to launch a network attack on another container or cluster. To disable the CAP_NET_RAW capability, the appropriate Security Context Constraints (SCCs) should set NET_RAW in requiredDropCapabilities.
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:warning: This rule's check operates on the cluster configuration dump. Therefore, you need to use a tool that can query the OCP API, retreive the /apis/security.openshift.io/v1/securitycontextconstraints API endpoint to the local /apis/security.openshift.io/v1/securitycontextconstraints file.
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:rationale: By default, containers run with a default set of capabilities as assigned by the Container Runtime which can include dangerous or highly privileged capabilities. If the CAP_NET_RAW is enabled, it may be misused by malicious containers or attackers.

xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:title: Limit Access to the Host IPC Namespace
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:description: Containers should not be allowed access to the host's Interprocess Commication (IPC) namespace. To prevent containers from getting access to a host's IPC namespace, the appropriate Security Context Constraints (SCCs) should set allowHostIPC to false.
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:warning: This rule's check operates on the cluster configuration dump. Therefore, you need to use a tool that can query the OCP API, retreive the /apis/security.openshift.io/v1/securitycontextconstraints API endpoint to the local /apis/security.openshift.io/v1/securitycontextconstraints file.
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:rationale: A container running in the host's IPC namespace can use IPC to interact with processes outside the container potentially allowing an attacker to exploit a host process thereby enabling an attacker to exploit other services.

xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:title: Drop Container Capabilities
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:description: Containers should not enable more capabilites than needed as this opens the door for malicious use. To disable the capabilities, the appropriate Security Context Constraints (SCCs) should set all capabilities as * or a list of capabilities in requiredDropCapabilities.
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:warning: This rule's check operates on the cluster configuration dump. Therefore, you need to use a tool that can query the OCP API, retreive the /apis/security.openshift.io/v1/securitycontextconstraints API endpoint to the local /apis/security.openshift.io/v1/securitycontextconstraints file.
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:rationale: By default, containers run with a default set of capabilities as assigned by the Container Runtime which can include dangerous or highly privileged capabilities. Capabilities should be dropped unless absolutely critical for the container to run software as added capabilities that are not required allow for malicious containers or attackers.

xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:title: Limit Access to the Host Network Namespace
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:description: Containers should not be allowed access to the host's network namespace. To prevent containers from getting access to a host's network namespace, the appropriate Security Context Constraints (SCCs) should set allowHostNetwork to false.
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:warning: This rule's check operates on the cluster configuration dump. Therefore, you need to use a tool that can query the OCP API, retreive the /apis/security.openshift.io/v1/securitycontextconstraints API endpoint to the local /apis/security.openshift.io/v1/securitycontextconstraints file.
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:rationale: A container running in the host's network namespace could access the host network traffic to and from other pods potentially allowing an attacker to exploit pods and network traffic.

xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:title: Limit Access to the Host Process ID Namespace
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:description: Containers should not be allowed access to the host's process ID namespace. To prevent containers from getting access to a host's process ID namespace, the appropriate Security Context Constraints (SCCs) should set allowHostPID to false.
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:warning: This rule's check operates on the cluster configuration dump. Therefore, you need to use a tool that can query the OCP API, retreive the /apis/security.openshift.io/v1/securitycontextconstraints API endpoint to the local /apis/security.openshift.io/v1/securitycontextconstraints file.
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:rationale: A container running in the host's PID namespace can inspect processes running outside the container which can be used to escalate privileges outside of the container.

xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:title: Limit Container Running As Root User
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:description: Containers should be limited to only the privileges required to run and should very rarely be run as root user. To prevent containers from running as root user, the appropriate Security Context Constraints (SCCs) should set allowPrivilegedContainer to false.
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:rationale: Privileged containers have access to all Linux Kernel capabilities and devices. If a privileged container were compromised, an attacker would have full access to the container and host.

xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:title: Limit Privileged Container Use
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:description: Containers should be limited to only the privileges required to run. To prevent containers from running as privileged containers, the appropriate Security Context Constraints (SCCs) should set allowPrivilegedContainer to false.
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:warning: This rule's check operates on the cluster configuration dump. Therefore, you need to use a tool that can query the OCP API, retreive the /apis/security.openshift.io/v1/securitycontextconstraints API endpoint to the local /apis/security.openshift.io/v1/securitycontextconstraints file.
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:rationale: Privileged containers have access to all Linux Kernel capabilities and devices. If a privileged container were compromised, an attacker would have full access to the container and host.

xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:title: Limit Container Capabilities
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:description: Containers should not enable more capabilites than needed as this opens the door for malicious use. To enable only the required capabilities, the appropriate Security Context Constraints (SCCs) should set capabilities as a list in allowedCapabilities.
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:rationale: By default, containers run with a default set of capabilities as assigned by the Container Runtime which can include dangerous or highly privileged capabilities. Capabilities should be dropped unless absolutely critical for the container to run software as added capabilities that are not required allow for malicious containers or attackers.

xccdf-1.2:Group.xccdf-1.2:title: OpenShift - Kubernetes - Scheduler Settings
xccdf-1.2:Group.xccdf-1.2:description: Contains evaluations for kube-scheduler configuration settings.

xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:title: Ensure that the bind-address parameter is not used
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:description: The Scheduler API service which runs on port 10251/TCP by default is used for health and metrics information and is available without authentication or encryption. As such it should only be bound to a localhost interface, to minimize the cluster's attack surface.
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:warning: This rule's check operates on the cluster configuration dump. Therefore, you need to use a tool that can query the OCP API, retreive the /api/v1/namespaces/openshift-kube-scheduler/configmaps/kube-scheduler-pod API endpoint to the local /api/v1/namespaces/openshift-kube-scheduler/configmaps/kube-scheduler-pod file.
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:rationale: In OpenShift 4, The Kubernetes Scheduler operator manages and updates the Kubernetes Scheduler deployed on top of OpenShift. By default, the operator exposes metrics via metrics service. The metrics are collected from the Kubernetes Scheduler operator. Profiling data is sent to healthzPort, the port of the localhost healthz endpoint. Changing this value may disrupt components that monitor the kubelet health.

xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:title: Ensure that the port parameter is zero
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:description: The Scheduler API service which runs on port 10251/TCP by default is used for health and metrics information and is available without authentication or encryption. As such it should only be bound to a localhost interface, to minimize the cluster's attack surface.
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:warning: This rule's check operates on the cluster configuration dump. Therefore, you need to use a tool that can query the OCP API, retreive the /api/v1/namespaces/openshift-kube-scheduler/configmaps/kube-scheduler-pod API endpoint to the local /api/v1/namespaces/openshift-kube-scheduler/configmaps/kube-scheduler-pod file.
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:rationale: In OpenShift 4, The Kubernetes Scheduler operator manages and updates the Kubernetes Scheduler deployed on top of OpenShift. By default, the operator exposes metrics via metrics service. The metrics are collected from the Kubernetes Scheduler operator. Profiling data is sent to healthzPort, the port of the localhost healthz endpoint. Changing this value may disrupt components that monitor the kubelet health.

xccdf-1.2:Group.xccdf-1.2:title: Kubernetes Kubelet Settings
xccdf-1.2:Group.xccdf-1.2:description:
The Kubernetes Kubelet is an agent that runs on each node in the cluster. It makes sure that containers are running in a pod.
The kubelet takes a set of PodSpecs that are provided through various mechanisms and ensures that the containers described in those PodSpecs are running and healthy. The kubelet doesn’t manage containers which were not created by Kubernetes.

xccdf-1.2:Value.xccdf-1.2:title: kubelet - Authorization Options
xccdf-1.2:Value.xccdf-1.2:description:
ABAC - Attribute-Based Access Control (ABAC) mode allows you to configure policies using local files.
RBAC - Role-based access control (RBAC) mode allows you to create and store policies using the Kubernetes API.
Webhook - WebHook is an HTTP callback mode that allows you to manage authorization using a remote REST endpoint.
Node Node - authorization is a special-purpose authorization mode that specifically authorizes API requests made by kubelets.
AlwaysDeny - This flag blocks all requests. Use this flag only for testing.

xccdf-1.2:Value.xccdf-1.2:title: Streaming Connection Timeout Options
xccdf-1.2:Value.xccdf-1.2:description: Time until connection timeouts. Use (s) for seconds, (m) for minutes, and (h) for hours.

xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:title: kubelet - Enable Certificate Rotation
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:description:
To enable the kubelet to rotate client certificates, edit the kubelet configuration file /etc/kubernetes/kubernetes.conf on the kubelet node(s) and set the below parameter:
... rotateCertificates: true ...
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:rationale: Allowing the kubelet to auto-update the certificates ensure that there is no downtime in certificate renewal as well as ensures confidentiality and integrity.

xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:title: kubelet - Do Not Limit Event Creation
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:description:
All events should be captured and not restricted as this helps in reconstucting the chain-of-events.
To prevent log creation limiting, edit the kubelet configuration file /etc/kubernetes/kubernetes.conf on the kubelet node(s) and set the below parameter: eventRecordQPS: 0
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:rationale: All events should be captured and not restricted as this helps in reconstucting the chain-of-events.

xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:title: kubelet - Enable Server Certificate Rotation
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:description:
To enable the kubelet to rotate server certificates, edit the kubelet configuration file /etc/kubernetes/kubernetes.conf on the kubelet node(s) and set the below parameter:
featureGates: ... RotateKubeletServerCertificate: true ...
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:rationale: Allowing the kubelet to auto-update the certificates ensure that there is no downtime in certificate renewal as well as ensures confidentiality and integrity.

xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:title: Ensure That The kubelet Client Certificate Is Correctly Set
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:description: To ensure the kubelet TLS client certificate is configured, edit the kubelet configuration file /etc/kubernetes/kubernetes.conf and configure the kubelet certificate file. tlsCertFile: /path/to/TLS/cert.key
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:warning: This rule's check operates on the cluster configuration dump. Therefore, you need to use a tool that can query the OCP API, retreive the /api/v1/namespaces/openshift-kube-apiserver/configmaps/config API endpoint to the local /api/v1/namespaces/openshift-kube-apiserver/configmaps/config file.
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:rationale: Without cryptographic integrity protections, information can be altered by unauthorized users without detection.

xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:title: kubelet - Do Not Disable Streaming Timeouts
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:description: Timouts for streaming connections should not be disabled as they help to prevent denial-of-service attacks. To configure streaming connection timeouts, edit the kubelet configuration file /etc/kubernetes/kubelet.conf on the kubelet node(s) and set the below parameter: streamingConnectionIdleTimeout:
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:rationale: Ensuring connections have timeouts helps to protect against denial-of-service attacks as well as disconnect inactive connections. In addition, setting connections timeouts helps to prevent from running out of ephemeral ports.

xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:title: kubelet - Disable the Read-Only Port
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:description:
To disable the read-only port, edit the kubelet configuration Edit the openshift-kube-apiserver configmap on the master node(s) and set the kubelet-read-only-port parameter to 0:
"apiServerArguments":{ ... "kubelet-read-only-port":[ "0" ], ...
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:warning: This rule's check operates on the cluster configuration dump. Therefore, you need to use a tool that can query the OCP API, retreive the /api/v1/namespaces/openshift-kube-apiserver/configmaps/config API endpoint to the local /api/v1/namespaces/openshift-kube-apiserver/configmaps/config file.
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:rationale: OpenShift disables the read-only port (10255) on all nodes by setting the read-only port kubelet flag to 0. This ensures only authenticated connections are able to receive information about the OpenShift system.

xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:title: kubelet - Allow Automatic Firewall Configuration
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:description: The kubelet has the ability to automatically configure the firewall to allow the containers required ports and connections to networking resources and destinations parameters potentially creating a security incident. To allow the kubelet to modify the firewall, edit the kubelet configuration file /etc/kubernetes/kubelet.conf on the kubelet node(s) and set the below parameter: makeIPTablesUtilChains: true
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:rationale: The kubelet should automatically configure the firewall settings to allow access and networking traffic through. This ensures that when a pod or container is running that the correct ports are configured as well as removing the ports when a pod or container is no longer in existence.

xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:title: kubelet - Configure the Client CA Certificate
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:description:
By default, the kubelet is not configured with a CA certificate which can subject the kubelet to man-in-the-middle attacks.
