xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:rationale: The Kube specification file contains information about the configuration of the OpenShift API Server that is configured on the system. Protection of this file is critical for OpenShift security.

xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:title: Verify Permissions on the OpenShift Open vSwitch Files
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:description: To properly set the permissions of /etc/openvswitch/.*, run the command: $ sudo chmod 0644 /etc/openvswitch/.*
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:rationale: CNI (Container Network Interface) files consist of a specification and libraries for writing plugins to configure network interfaces in Linux containers, along with a number of supported plugins. Allowing writeable access to the files could allow an attacker to modify the networking configuration potentially adding a rogue network connection.

xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:title: Verify Permissions on the Kube Controller Manager Pod Specificiation File
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:description: To properly set the permissions of /etc/kubernetes/static-pod-resources/kube-controller-manager-pod-.*/kube-controller-manager-pod.yaml, run the command: $ sudo chmod 0644 /etc/kubernetes/static-pod-resources/kube-controller-manager-pod-.*/kube-controller-manager-pod.yaml
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:rationale: If the Kube specification file is writable by a group-owner or the world the risk of its compromise is increased. The file contains the configuration of an OpenShift Controller Manager server that is configured on the system. Protection of this file is critical for OpenShift security.

xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:title: Verify Permissions on the OpenShift Admin Kubeconfig Files
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:description: To properly set the permissions of /etc/kubernetes/static-pod-resources/kube-apiserver-certs/secrets/node-kubeconfigs/.*\.kubeconfig, run the command: $ sudo chmod 0600 /etc/kubernetes/static-pod-resources/kube-apiserver-certs/secrets/node-kubeconfigs/.*\.kubeconfig
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:rationale: There are various kubeconfig files that can be used by the administrator, defining various settings for the administration of the cluster. These files contain credentials that can be used to control the cluster and are needed for disaster recovery and each kubeconfig points to a different endpoint in the cluster. You should restrict its file permissions to maintain the integrity of the kubeconfig file as an attacker who gains access to these files can take over the cluster.

xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:title: Verify User Who Owns The OpenShift SDN CNI Server Config
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:description: To properly set the owner of /var/run/openshift-sdn/cniserver/config.json, run the command: $ sudo chown root /var/run/openshift-sdn/cniserver/config.json
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:rationale: CNI (Container Network Interface) files consist of a specification and libraries for writing plugins to configure network interfaces in Linux containers, along with a number of supported plugins. Allowing writeable access to the files could allow an attacker to modify the networking configuration potentially adding a rogue network connection.

xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:title: Verify Permissions on the Etcd Write-Ahead-Log Files
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:description: To properly set the permissions of /var/lib/etcd/member/wal/.*, run the command: $ sudo chmod 0600 /var/lib/etcd/member/wal/.*
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:rationale: etcd is a highly-available key-value store used by Kubernetes deployments for persistent storage of all of its REST API objects. This data directory should be protected from any unauthorized reads or writes. It should not be readable or writable by any group members or the world.

xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:title: Verify User Who Owns The OpenShift Open vSwitch Files
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:description: To properly set the owner of /etc/openvswitch/.*, run the command: $ sudo chown root /etc/openvswitch/.*
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:rationale: CNI (Container Network Interface) files consist of a specification and libraries for writing plugins to configure network interfaces in Linux containers, along with a number of supported plugins. Allowing writeable access to the files could allow an attacker to modify the networking configuration potentially adding a rogue network connection.

xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:title: Verify Group Who Owns The OpenShift Admin Kubeconfig Files
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:description: To properly set the group owner of /etc/kubernetes/static-pod-resources/kube-apiserver-certs/secrets/node-kubeconfigs/.*\.kubeconfig, run the command: $ sudo chgrp root /etc/kubernetes/static-pod-resources/kube-apiserver-certs/secrets/node-kubeconfigs/.*\.kubeconfig
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:rationale: There are various kubeconfig files that can be used by the administrator, defining various settings for the administration of the cluster. You should restrict its file permissions to maintain the integrity of the kubeconfig file as an attacker who gains access to these files can take over the cluster.

You should restrict its file permissions to maintain the integrity of the kubeconfig file as an attacker who gains access to these files can take over the cluster.

xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:title: Verify Permissions on the Kubernetes Scheduler Kubeconfig File
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:description: To properly set the permissions of /etc/kubernetes/static-pod-resources/kube-scheduler-pod-.*/configmaps/scheduler-kubeconfig/kubeconfig, run the command: $ sudo chmod 0644 /etc/kubernetes/static-pod-resources/kube-scheduler-pod-.*/configmaps/scheduler-kubeconfig/kubeconfig
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:rationale: The kubeconfig for the Scheduler contains paramters for the scheduler to access the Kube API. You should restrict its file permissions to maintain the integrity of the file. The file should be writable by only the administrators on the system.

xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:title: Verify Group Who Owns The Open vSwitch Configuration Database
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:description: To properly set the group owner of /etc/openvswitch/conf.db, run the command: $ sudo chgrp openvswitch /etc/openvswitch/conf.db
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:rationale: CNI (Container Network Interface) files consist of a specification and libraries for writing plugins to configure network interfaces in Linux containers, along with a number of supported plugins. Allowing writeable access to the files could allow an attacker to modify the networking configuration potentially adding a rogue network connection.

xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:title: Verify Group Who Owns The OpenShift PKI Private Key Files
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:description: To properly set the group owner of /etc/kubernetes/static-pod-resources/.*/.*/.*/.*\.key, run the command: $ sudo chgrp root /etc/kubernetes/static-pod-resources/.*/.*/.*/.*\.key
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:rationale: OpenShift makes use of a number of certificates as part of its operation. You should verify the ownership of the directory containing the PKI information and all files in that directory to maintain their integrity. The directory and files should be owned by root:root.

xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:title: Verify User Who Owns The Open vSwitch Persistent System ID
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:description: To properly set the owner of /etc/openvswitch/system-id.conf, run the command: $ sudo chown openvswitch /etc/openvswitch/system-id.conf
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:rationale: CNI (Container Network Interface) files consist of a specification and libraries for writing plugins to configure network interfaces in Linux containers, along with a number of supported plugins. Allowing writeable access to the files could allow an attacker to modify the networking configuration potentially adding a rogue network connection.

xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:title: Verify Group Who Owns The ETCD Member Pod Specification File
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:description: To properly set the group owner of /etc/kubernetes/static-pod-resources/etcd-pod-.*/etcd-pod.yaml, run the command: $ sudo chgrp root /etc/kubernetes/static-pod-resources/etcd-pod-.*/etcd-pod.yaml
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:rationale: The Kube Specification file contains information about the configuration of the OpenShift scheduler that is configured on the system. Protection of this file is critical for OpenShift security.

xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:title: Verify Group Who Owns The Etcd PKI Certificate Files
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:description: To properly set the group owner of /etc/kubernetes/static-pod-resources/.*/.*/.*/.*\.internal\.crt, run the command: $ sudo chgrp root /etc/kubernetes/static-pod-resources/.*/.*/.*/.*\.internal\.crt
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:rationale: OpenShift makes use of a number of certificates as part of its operation. You should verify the ownership of the directory containing the PKI information and all files in that directory to maintain their integrity. The directory and files should be owned by the system administrator.

xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:title: Verify Group Who Owns The Etcd Database Directory
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:description: To properly set the group owner of /var/lib/etcd/member/, run the command: $ sudo chgrp root /var/lib/etcd/member/
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:rationale: etcd is a highly-available key-value store used by Kubernetes deployments for persistent storage of all of its REST API objects. This data directory should be protected from any unauthorized reads or writes.

xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:title: Verify Group Who Owns The Kubernetes Scheduler Kubeconfig File
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:description: To properly set the group owner of /etc/kubernetes/static-pod-resources/kube-scheduler-pod-.*/configmaps/scheduler-kubeconfig/kubeconfig, run the command: $ sudo chgrp root /etc/kubernetes/static-pod-resources/kube-scheduler-pod-.*/configmaps/scheduler-kubeconfig/kubeconfig
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:rationale: The kubeconfig for the Scheduler contains paramters for the scheduler to access the Kube API. You should set its file ownership to maintain the integrity of the file.

xccdf-1.2:Group.xccdf-1.2:title: OpenShift - General Security Practices
xccdf-1.2:Group.xccdf-1.2:description: Contains evaluations for general security practices for operating an OpenShift environment.

xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:title: Manage Image Provenance Using ImagePolicyWebhook
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:description:
OpenShift administrators can control which images can be imported, tagged, and run in a cluster. There are two facilities for this purpose: (1) Allowed Registries, allowing administrators to restrict image origins to known external registries; and (2) ImagePolicy Admission plug-in which lets administrators specify specific images which are allowed to run on the OpenShift cluster.
Configure an Image policy per the Image Policy chapter in the OpenShift documentation:
https://docs.openshift.com/container-platform/4.4/openshift_images/image-configuration.html
xccdf-1.2:Rule.xccdf-1.2:rationale: Image Policy ensures that only approved container images are allowed to be ran on the OpenShift platform.
